awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Continuation of the Dark Matter Search with XENON1T at LNGS
awd_abstract_narration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of normal atoms, but must be otherwise undetected elementary "dark matter" particles that do not emit or absorb light. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. A leading hypothesis is that it is comprised of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, that were produced moments after the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our galaxy may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in detectors located deep underground to help reject backgrounds due to cosmic rays. Direct detection of WIMP dark matter would solve a fundamental mystery in particle physics and cosmology, providing a unique window to learning about the primary matter constituent of the Universe and of physics beyond the Standard Model of particle physics. This award supports the US groups involved in the XENON1T dark matter search program at the INFN Gran Sasso National Laboratory (LNGS) underground laboratory.

The XENON project continues to captivate the imagination of the public. This is evidenced, for example, by several TV shows such as "The Big Bang Theory", which on several occasions featured XENON plots and results. Public interest in science is encouraged through talks and outreach activities. XENON1T will play a significant role in solving the dark matter puzzle, by either detecting WIMPs, or putting them under immense pressure as viable dark matter candidates. In addressing this fundamental physics problem, these awards will engage many undergraduate and graduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers, exposing them to a variety of subjects in physics and cosmology, and training them in state-of-the-art technologies, thus preparing to become future leaders in the field. Finally, the instrumentation and techniques used in XENON are relevant to a wide range of applications, from areas in homeland security and medical imaging, to the analysis and statistical treatment of large data sets.

The program for the next four years will focus on the continued operation of the XENON1T experiment and its science data analysis. The international XENON Collaboration of 130 scientists continues to be led by the PI at Columbia University with key roles served by US members both in the management of the experiment and its scientific program. XENON1T uses the largest liquid xenon time projection chamber (TPC) built to-date, with 2 tonnes active Xe target, and the highest sensitivity to dark matter Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs), at the level of 2 × 10^-47 cm^2 for 40 GeV WIMPs. With funding of this proposal, the US will remain in the lead of the direct search for dark matter well beyond the end of the decade.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative award allowed the US groups of the XENON collaboration to play leading roles in the operation and analysis of data from XENON1T, the world’s first tonne-scale liquid xenon detector for the direct search of dark matter. XENON1T was installed and operated at the Gran Sasso Underground Laboratory in Italy.

During the reporting period, the XENON1T experiment achieved the lowest background in the signal region expected from Weakly Interacting Massive Particle (WIMP) dark matter. Thus, the collaboration obtained the most stringent constraints for dark matter interacting with the ordinary matter, for dark matter masses above about half a proton mass.

The collaboration developed experimental techniques to reduce trace radioactive elements from the detector’s target to the lowest level ever achieved in any dark matter detector. This allowed the experiment to achieve unprecedented low levels of electronic recoil background. In turn, XENON1T was not only extraordinarily sensitive to WIMP dark matter, but also to a number of other rare processes in nature and particle theories beyond the Standard Model. With XENON1T, the collaborating groups observed for the first time the rare double-electron capture process of Xe-124 element, the longest decay process that was ever directly measured. The collaboration also found an unexplained excess in the rate of low-energy electronic recoil events. This excess will be further studied using the upgraded XENONnT experiment, which is already in operation at the same location and with even lower electronic recoil background.

The wide energy range of data collected by the XENON1T detector allowed the collaboration to expand its science program from dark matter to other rare process from searching for light dark matter, with its mass lighter than the proton mass, scattering on the electrons, solar neutrinos coherent scattering on nuclei, and the search for neutrinoless double beta decay of the Xe-136 element. Stringent constraints and limits were set using XENON1T data. Further investigation of this rich science will be continued in the XENONnT experiment, based on the experience from XENON1T operation and data analysis.

The mystery of dark matter and heroic effort to search for it using deep underground detectors continue to captivate the interest of next-generation scientists. The program has attracted an outstanding number of undergraduates for the research experience by using the data collected and analyzed remotely. More than ten graduate students and postdocs were trained through this program during this period, with some becoming leading figures in the collaboration from detector operation to science data analysis. A planetarium show that has been seen by an estimated one million people across the globe has been produced as part of this award. The liquid xenon detector technology developed in this program also allowed the development of applications from medical imaging to nuclear safeguards in some of the participating groups.
